Desolation-valley.title: Desolation valley
Desolation-valley.content:
www.facebook.com/search/top/%20valley%20namibia
On Friday morning, 8th December, the group of ten vehicles left the small town of Uis, to commence the adventourous trip. They first went up to Landcruiser Hill, then visited the Burnt Mnt, Twyfelfontein and drove down into the Aba-Huab dry river bed and further into the Huab dry river bed. Stop over was at Mushroom Hill and thereafter the group drove into Desolation Valey, visited the Gai-Ais Fountain, as well as a Petified Forest. Afterwards they drove down the Gai-Ais Canyon, then traversed into Zebra Canyon. An old mine shaft was inspected on their way to the Brandberg West pass. The trip then continued up the Ugab and Divorce Pass, where one could walk among a stone Labyrinth situated on a hill. Afterwards they turn off towards Land Cruiser Hill, passing some of Namibiaâ€™s famous fairy circles, then drove down Landcruiser Hill. A quick stop was made at De Rust and the trip ended up at White Lady Lodge.
Great impressions were the geological foundations as well as the fauna and flora, which had come to life after the arid area had received some early rains. Animals seen were Desert Adapted Elephants, Black Rhino, Giraffe, Springbok various other small animals.

Erongo Region
This region comprises the Swakopmund magisterial district up to the Ugab river and includes the enclave of Walvis Bay, formerÂ DamaralandÂ south of the Ugab river, and the Omaruru and Karibib magisterial districts. This region is named after the Erongo mountain, a well known landmark in Namibia and in this area. All the main centres within this region, excepting south of former Damaraland, are connected by tarred roads. Gravel roads link this this part with either Omaruru or Swakopmund. The inclusion of former South Damaraland is necessitated by various services for this part which originate in Omaruru. Postal and telecommunications services for Omatjette, Okombahe and Uis are maintained from Omaruru. Veterinary services for these areas are provided by the State Veterinarian based at Omaruru. The maintenance of roads falls under the Roads Superintendent of Omaruru. Medical services are rendered at the clinics of Omatjette, Okombahe, and Uis by medical personnel and private doctors stationed at Omaruru. The main hospital centre for this area is in Omaruru.
The Omaruru, Karibib and Okombahe/Uis/Tsubeses areas are all situated in a semi-arid farming region and have a homogenous farming pattern, which is mostly stock-raising. It also combines communal farming with commercial farming. The needs for production and marketing are therefore very similar and the farming community has a distinct mutual interest which distinguishes their area from the Okahandja/Otjiwarongo areas which are different in various aspects.
Various mining operations occur within this region at places such asÂ NavachabÂ and on a smaller scale at places surrounding Uis and the desert area. Karibib also has a marble industry. Walvis Bay is the principle home of Namibiaâ€™s fishing industry. Arandis supports mining industry and Swakopmund boasts manufacturing. Arandis is also anÂ Export Processing Zone (EPZ).
This region, with its link to the coast of Namibia, is well developed and should not experience any difficulty in functioning as an administrative unit. Facilities such as schools, hospitals and clinics, the supply of electricity and telecommunication services are, with a few exceptions, well established. The linkage of this predominantly farming area with the more developed areas such as Swakopmund and Walvis Bay is territorially justified and can only be to their advantage.
The region comprises of six constituencies: Omaruru, Karibib, Brandberg, Arandis, Swakopmund, Walvis Bay.
Kunene Region
This region comprises the western part of former Ovambo, Koakoland, Damaraland north of the Ugab river and the Magisterial District of Outjo. This region is named after the Kunene river which forms the north-western border of this particular region. With its large supply of water and its hydro-electric plant, this river will play an increasingly important role in NamibiaÂ 
The main centers of this region are connected by gravel and tarred roads. Opuwo, Khorixas, Kamanjab and Ruacana are linked with constructed gravel roads whereas Khorixas and Kamanjab are in turn linked to Outjo by tarred roads. The communication system of this region, excepting Ruacana, runs from Outjo and is maintained from this centre. The railway line serving most of Region ends at Outjo from where consumer items and other goods are distributed through the region.
One of the unique features of this region is its many tourist attractions. Places such as former Kaokoland, Damaraland and Ruacana will become more accessible to tourists once the planned tarred road running from Ruacana to Kamanjab and the coast becomes a reality. With Outjo as one of the two entrance points to the National Etosha Game Reserve, tourism will become a major revenue source to this territory which is otherwise somewhat underendowed with natural resources.Â 
At its main centers, the region has facilities such as primary and secondary schools, clinics and hospitals and electrical power supply. Although these facilities are not always sufficient to provide for all the needs of the community, the necessary infrastructure for further development is available.Â 
Furthermore a lively trade has developed between this western part of former Ovambo and more particularly the people of former eastern Kaokoland. There is also evidence that people from former Ovambo have moved into former Kaokoland and vice versa.Â 
The region has been divided into the following six constituencies: Ruacana, Opuwo, Sesfontein, Khorixas, Kamanjab and Outjo.

Trip details
**Herewith a very short summary of the Namibia tour that is on offer:**  
  
Kaokoland and Damaraland safari with Khwela Adventures & Specialised Adventures  
  
  
This includes the following:  
  
- All the accommodation fees in Namibia  
- Tent, stretcher, mattress & camping chair  
- All cutlery & crockery  
- Breakfast, lunch packs & supper  
- Fresh water and Cold drinks  
- Ice when available - 60% of the trip  
- Backup and recovery vehicles  
- Medical officer  
- Aerial evacuation arrangements with an Evacuation Company. (You will need to notify your medical aid of your intention to ride in Namibia and send us written confirmation of coverage)  
- Fuel for your bike in the areas where no fuel is available - with the understanding that you fill your bike where it is available. (budget around R1000 for it)  
- Daily briefing on the route for the day.  
- Tracks and routes (depending on your preferred format) uploaded to your GPS.  
- Tools.  
- Compressors.  
- Puncture repair equipment.  
- Satellite phone (For emergencies in the remote areas, where there is no Wi-Fi and you need to re-assure the plaintiff that you are in fact still alive)  
Â   
Our route for the Namibia tour will take you through Damaraland and Kaokoland and you will ride through and see places like Spitzkoppe, Van Zyl's pass, the Marienfluss, Purros Canyon, Brandberg and much more. Our Namibia trips are usually 12 days in total.  
  
We will also assist in getting your bike to Namibia and back wherever possible at a very reasonable fee. We are based in Loxton and Pretoria and riders that fly to Windhoek will have to get their bikes to us.  
  
We can only take 16 riders per trip, so please make sure you book asap.  
  
These trips are not races. It is a true dual sport adventure in one of the most beautiful and fascinating places on earth. The average rider will in all likelihood stop and take pictures 20 times a day. You will need some degree of skill and experience as we will ride some sand and rocky mountain passes during the trip.  
  
You will have to ride with a camel back, and take re-hydrates daily, as dehydration becomes your worst enemy in the desert.  
  
  
I highly recommend that you give Hardy (our tour leader) a call for any questions that you may have. He would be the best person to speak to regarding the area's where we conduct our tours, as well as any logistical questions you may have. His number is 082 784 0729

Khowarib is a little community smack bang on the C43 en route to Opuwo. Itâ€™s not well known, but thatâ€™s precisely what makes it so special. Itâ€™s a hidden gem and a wonderful place to stop to break up the long journey in Kaokoland, especially if youâ€™re on your way to Opuwo from destinations further south.Â 
What makes it so special? Well, Khowarib is set at precisely the position where the desert begins to meet the tropics. Thereâ€™s still a desert vibe, but vegetation becomes more lush and â€“ gasp! â€“ thereâ€™s even water in the river! It reminds us of the area around theÂ Jatbula TrailÂ in Australia.Â 
With not a lot of visitors, Khowarib is also incredibly tranquil. Thereâ€™s not a ton to do here, but if itâ€™s relaxing youâ€™re after, look no further.Â

Where to Get Supplies in Kaokoland
Opuwo is pretty much the only place to stock up on supplies in Kaokoland. Be sure to stock up well, because once you leave Opuwo, you wonâ€™t find a hell of a lot else.Â 
Fortunately, you can find most services you need in Opuwo. There are two supermarkets: an OK Food and a Spar â€“ OK Food has a better selection than Spar. There are a number of pharmacies in town if you need any medication.Â 
There are plenty of fuel stations and, helpfully, a solid mechanic if you need to get work done or buy a new tire (trust us, you might). If you find yourself in need of tires or a repair, head to Kunene Outfitters, which is in the orange and black building near the OK Food.Â 
There are a number of roadside tire repair places in Kaokoland, but they donâ€™t always do the best job. If you need some work on our tires, youâ€™re best off doing so in Opuwo.

Weather---Rainfall.title: Weather - Rainfall
Weather---Rainfall.content:
Damaraland has a semi-desert climate with a highly variable annual rainfall of aboutÂ 13 to 20 inches (330 to 500 mm), with the rainy season typically occurring between November and April.Â Multi-year droughts are common, but occasional heavy rainfall events can happen, sometimes leading to flooding in low-lying areas.Â 
Rainfall patterns

Seasonal:Â 
The main rainy season is from November to April, with occasional thunderstorms in November and peak rainfall from January to March.Â 
Annual average:Â 
The average annual rainfall is approximately 13 to 20 inches (330 to 500 mm), though this can vary significantly.Â 
Variability:Â 
Rainfall is highly variable, and multi-year droughts are a common feature of the regionâ€™s climate.Â 
Rare events:Â 
Exceptionally heavy rainfall can occur, sometimes described as â€œonce-in-a-decadeâ€ events.Â 
Effects of heavy rain:Â 
These rare downpours can cause significant, localized flooding because the ground is not used to absorbing large amounts of water, and drainage systems are minimal.Â 

Recent rainfall events

Summer 2025:Â 
The region experienced a significant â€œonce-in-a-decadeâ€ rainfall event in the summer of 2025.
Impact:Â 
This rainfall brought new life to the desert, with rivers flowing, vegetation blooming, and improved conditions for the local wildlife, such as the desert-adapted black rhino.


Damaraland weather in August
Our temperatures ranged from 14Â° Celsius mornings to 33Â° during the day, plus weâ€™ve had very misty mornings for the past two months. Fog has covered the mountain, creating unique and lovely light as the sun rises through it. It stays for few minutes after the sun has climbed a little, and then burns off to produce sunny days. Itâ€™s the first time we are experiencing this in spring for a decade.
This special spring has created the perfect opportunities for outdoor games and bush breakfasts â€“ and with the beautiful colour all over the mountain, it feels like the landscape is finally waking up after the long, cold winter.
Wildlife
The wildlife has become very active too, their movement marked by migrations, breeding, and the birth and care of young ones. Animals are emerging from hibernation, migratory birds are returning, and the plants have new growth. This period sees increased birdsong, and we have more guineafowls than we can count.Â 
Weâ€™ve seen gentle giraffes following the stream in camp, just a few metres from Rooms 9 and 10, with a beautiful sighting of a giraffe picking fresh leaves in view of camp.Â 
Itâ€™s a vital time for reproduction and foraging, making it a fascinating season for observing nature. With the blooming of flowers, early spring flies, butterflies and bees are more visible. That said, we are very cautious around the animals as too, as they may be nesting or sheltering. We keep a very safe distance from breeding herds of elephants as they are very protective.

Hereâ€™s a detailed summary of what you can expect weather-wise in Damaraland and Kaokaveld (North-West Namibia) in July, plus some practical tips for travelling in that period.

Damaraland






What the climate is like

August falls into the dry season for Damaraland (and much of Namibia) â€” low rainfall, clear skies. (Namibia Tours & Safaris)
Daytime maximum temperatures average around ~ 26-27 Â°C in July. (SafariBookings.com)
Night and early morning temperatures drop significantly â€” typical minimums around ~ 11-12 Â°C (and sometimes lower, even near freezing in more exposed or higher spots). (SafariBookings.com)
Rainfall is extremely low. Damaraland in August is very dry. (World Weather & Climate Information)

What that means in practice

Expect bright sunny days, good for outdoor activities, photography, wildlife spotting.
Mornings and evenings will be chilly, so layers are important â€” even a fleece or warm jacket would be wise for early morning drives/excursions.
Because of the low rainfall and dry conditions, wildlife (especially desertâ€adapted) tends to concentrate around limited water sources â€” good for viewing. (Namibia Tours & Safaris)
Because nights are cold, camping or staying in lessâ€insulated accommodation may feel quite brisk.

Travel tips

Pack a warm hat/scarf for early mornings.
Dress in layers: morning cool â†’ midday warmth â†’ evening cool again.
Choose activities after the early morning chill â€” youâ€™ll get the best of the day in midâ€morning to afternoon.
Stay hydrated and use sun protection â€” despite being winter, the sun is bright in the desert.
Roads will be dry and accessible (in the dry season) â€” fewer issues with mud or washâ€outs.


Kaokaveld (Kaokoland)






What the climate is like

July is also in the core of the dry winter season for the Kaokaveld region. (SafariBookings.com)
Daytime temperatures typically reach about ~ 20-24 Â°C in July in Kaokaveld. (Namibia Tours & Safaris)
Morning / night minimums can go quite low â€” sometimes ~ 6-11 Â°C or even lower in exposed areas. (Namibia Tours & Safaris)
Rainfall is extremely rare in this period â€” very dry and clear. (Expert Africa)

What that means in practice

Similar to Damaraland: clear skies, excellent visibility, and great for wildlife-spotting (e.g., desertâ€adapted elephants, rhino) because they converge on the few water sources. (Expert Africa)
Mornings are very cold, especially preâ€sunrise or early in the day.
Midday will feel quite pleasant (20-24 Â°C), perhaps even warm when the sun is strong.
Because the region can be remote, with fewer services and more rugged terrain, cold mornings plus long days of activity mean you should plan for comfort and safety.

Travel tips

Early starts will require warm layers (thermal base layer / fleece) and something windâ€resistant (winds pick up in deserts).
After lunch, youâ€™ll likely want lighter layers (short sleeves) but still some protection for the sun.
Evening again gets cold â€” plan for a warm drink / jacket by sunset.
Given remoteness: carry emergency supplies, ensure vehicle and gear are in good order, make sure your daily plan accounts for slower roads.
Given the dryness: respect conservation rules (water is precious), stick to established camps/roads.


Summary Comparison

Both regions share dry winter weather in July: minimal rain, clear skies, excellent for travel.
Damaraland: Daytime ~ 26-27 Â°C, nights ~ 11-12 Â°C; very dry; good for wildlife.
Kaokaveld: Daytime a bit cooler (~ 20-24 Â°C), nights potentially much colder (~ 6-11 Â°C); also very dry and fantastic for remote wilderness experiences.
In both areas, morning chill and significant diurnal temperature swing â†’ key to pack accordingly.
